thread.title: 'Clean coal' cheaper than renewable energy, lobby group claims
thread.title_full: 'Clean coal' cheaper than renewable energy, lobby group claims

author: Tom Iggulden
title: 'Clean coal' cheaper than renewable energy, lobby group claims
text:
Map: Australia 
A coal lobby group has claimed using "clean coal" would be a cheaper way to lower carbon emissions than renewable energy sources. 
It comes as the Federal Government contemplates how to change the rules for the Clean Energy Finance Corporation (CEFC), which currently is not allowed to invest in clean coal. 
The Global Carbon Capture and Storage Institute's Asia-Pacific general manager Alex Zapantis said his proposal was more economically viable than renewable energy. 
"If you compare apples with apples, which really needs to consider the cost of reliable 24/7 energy, what you find actually is that carbon capture storage is at least competitive," Mr Zapantis said. 
"In many instances [the cost is] lower cost than implementing renewable technologies such as wind and solar." 
Mr Zapantis said buying enough batteries to keep renewable power supplied to everyone would cost more than the process of stripping carbon from coal plant emissions and storing it underground. 
"Think of it this way: if you need to go to a hospital, you can rely on a bus service and hopefully the bus is there at the right time to take you to the hospital when you need to go," he said. 
"Or you can have an ambulance â€” the ambulance is going to cost you more, but actually the value of the ambulance is much higher." 
There is no serious proposal anywhere to have renewables power 100 per cent of Australia's energy, making Mr Zapantis's claim an exaggeration at the very least. 
But Chris Greig, a professor at the University of Queensland, said nonetheless, "clean coal" technology could contribute to lowering carbon emissions and should not be ignored. 
"Technically it stacks up very well," Professor Greig said. 
"I think it has to be economically viable, so it has to compete with other low-emissions technology, and that's got to be seen on a case-by-case basis." Subsidies needed for 'clean coal' to work: lobbyist 
The claims from the carbon capture and storage industry come as it hopes to convince the Government to offer it subsidies, or as the industry prefers to call it, "policy support". 
According to Mr Zapantis, that is no different to the renewable energy industry. 
"In exactly the same way that renewable technologies require some sort of policy support to build the business case for investment by the private sector, carbon capture storage needs similar policy support," Mr Zapantis said. 
Another potential policy option would simply be to tax carbon output in the electricity sector and let the market sort out the cheapest way to cut emissions, known as an emissions intensity scheme. Audio: Listen to Tom Iggulden's story (AM) 
Mr Zapantis is more ambivalent about that option. 
"It could be part of the policy mix, but some careful analysis would have to be done to make sure that the policies that are chosen by the Government of the day are the most efficient policies," he said. 
But Professor Greig has no doubts an emissions intensity scheme would be the most efficient way to lower the cost of reducing carbon emissions. 
"Without some sort of economic signal which puts a value on carbon emissions, or signal a price on carbon emissions, we can't expect a more expensive technology to compete with unabated technologies," he said.
